title: Test Scores
question_text: Which of the following situations does NOT describe a situation with sample means?

choices.text: Select $30\text{ students}$ for an after-school study session and determine how many out of the $30$ pass the next unit test.
Select $30\text{ students}$ for an after-school study session and determine their average score on the next unit test.
Randomly select $30\text{ students}$ for an after-school study session and another $30\text{ students}$ who are not allowed to go to the study session; compare the average score of the two groups.
Randomly select $30\text{ students}$ to take a unit test; next, have them all take an after-school study session before taking an equally hard unit test again. Examine the change in test scores.
All of the listed responses deal with sample means.

solution:
Choice 'A' is correct; this design deals with the number of kids who passed out of $30$, which is a proportion, not a sample mean.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'B' is incorrect; this deals with sample means of $1$ sample.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; this deals with sample means comparing $2$ samples.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; this deals with sample means involving matched pairs data.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; the answers have been proven and disproven above.
